big.process1D.filter
Interface FIRConvolver

All Known Implementing Classes:
CausalFiniteDifferences, CausalFIRFilter, EvenSymmetricFiniteDifferences, EvenSymmetricFIRFilter, GenericFIRFilter, OddSymmetricFIRFilter
public interface FIRConvolver

This abstract class encapsulates discrete-convolution operations on one-dimensional data.

Method Summary
 Data1D getConvolution(Data1D data)
          Returns a Data1D object containing the result of the discrete convolution between the original data and the filter which is given by its impulse response.
 Filter1D getImpulseResponse()
          Returns a view of this filter as a Filter1D object.
 void inPlaceConvolve(Data1D data)
          Updates data with the result of the discrete convolution between the original data and the filter which is given by its impulse response.
 

Method Detail

getConvolution

Data1D getConvolution(Data1D data)
Returns a Data1D object containing the result of the discrete convolution between the original data and the filter which is given by its impulse response. The data from data is not modified. Depending on the filter instance, the size and the boundary extension of the returned object may differ from that of the argument. Mathematically, the operation can be described by
∀k0 ∈ ℤ: y[k0] = ∑k ∈ ℤ h[k] x[k0 - k].

Parameters:
data - the data which need to be convolved. Depending on the filter instance, the size and the boundary extension of the returned data may differ from that of the argument.
Returns:
the result of the convolution.

getImpulseResponse

Filter1D getImpulseResponse()
Returns a view of this filter as a Filter1D object.

Returns:
the impulse response.

inPlaceConvolve

void inPlaceConvolve(Data1D data)
Updates data with the result of the discrete convolution between the original data and the filter which is given by its impulse response. Depending on the filter instance, the boundary extension of the returned object may differ from that of the argument, but not its size. Mathematically, the operation can be described by
∀k0 ∈ [0…K - 1]: y[k0] = ∑k ∈ ℤ h[k] x[k0 - k],
where y is the result of convolving the data x with the filter h, and where K is the number of samples data.size() of the argument.

Parameters:
data - the data which need to be convolved, which get overwritten by the result of the convolution. Depending on the filter instance, the boundary extension of the data may change.
